awd_titl_txt: Sustainable Materials and Manufacturing Virtual Square Table
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Combined with the increasing capabilities of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning algorithms and high throughput means for syntheses and materials characterization, advances in materials design have the potential to transform the modern industrial economy and address the urgent challenges of material waste and usage of natural resources. In this way, the United States is positioned to be a leader in sustainable materials and climate-friendly manufacturing processes. Moreover, the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI), which was introduced in 2011, has been widely recognized as one of the most significant developments in materials research over the past decade. Its re-envisioning of how computation, theory, and experiment can work together in never-before-seen ways resulted in a rapid transformation of the working paradigm for both US materials science and engineering and the broader community, which encompasses researchers from other disciplines including chemistry, physics, biology, mathematics, and computer science. In particular, its ability to: (a) create vast materials datasets; (b) encourage researchers from disparate disciplines to interact in meaningful ways; and (c) incentivize the open sharing and analysis of data led to the accelerated development of many new classes of materials. This strength can now be leveraged to readily grow key areas of national need. Here, we put forward that sustainable materials development and manufacturing is an international necessity to mitigate the effects of waste in our environment, and it is also a factor in the future economic vitality of many industries.

PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

By taking an MGI-based approach to sustainable materials and manufacturing, we will address this critical opportunity in a complete way such that one of the biggest challenges facing the nation, and the global community, can be addressed in a holistic manner. To this end, we will host a Square Table (ST) over the course of 2, half-day sessions to discuss strategies for advancing the science of sustainable materials and facilitating the adoption of their capabilities into manufacturing at large under the MGI umbrella. The main goal of implementing the ST concept is to provide structure and self-facilitated interactions among stakeholders who do not typically interact with one another and to bridge gaps that exist between industry, federal agencies, and academia in an open and unbiased manner. In this way, we anticipate that this event will provide a clear picture of the current status and future vision of the sustainable materials and manufacturing community. This ST cuts to the heart of one of the most pressing societal challenges, and it will necessarily bridge across multiple disciplines to have the desired impact. Critically, the organizers of the event recognize the need to welcome a diversity of voices, and they will implement a recruiting plan to attract researchers from a variety of backgrounds such that a diverse and inclusive approach is taken at the outset of addressing an opportunity that affects all people. Importantly, both established and early-career (e.g., postdoctoral researchers and untenured faculty members) researchers will be event participants. Moreover, the ST will ensure that participants will be present from large and small businesses, federal agencies, and host of geographically-disperse academic institutional types including Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) and Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This "Square Table" on Sustainable Polymers was organized with the support of the Division of Materials Research at the National Science Foundation. The Square Table format was employed to facilitate productive interactions and bridge gaps between various stakeholders involved in advancing the field. This particular event brought together representatives from industry, federal agencies, and academia, with the aim of developing proposed solutions to important questions in the sustainable polymer domain.

The objectives of the Square Table event encompassed addressing critical research pursuits in both basic and applied areas, identifying barriers to large-scale coordinated efforts among different sectors, exploring the necessary resources and training required to overcome these barriers, facilitating collaborative sharing of data and advanced modeling approaches, and fostering partnerships conducive to realizing a more sustainable future. The outcome of this event was a comprehensive report, freely available on ChemRxiv (DOI: 10.33774/chemrxiv-2021-1xjbc).

As highlighted in the report, we firmly believe that the discovery, development, and deployment of sustainable polymers, the building blocks of plastics, are crucial for the well-being of our planet and its inhabitants. The report emphasizes the urgent need for change in order to address the pressing issues associated with plastics, which are integral to modern society but also contribute to pollution and environmental damage through waste accumulation and greenhouse gas emissions.

Acknowledging the advantages of plastics in our society alongside their negative environmental impact, it is evident that new approaches are essential. The NSF-sponsored Square Table event brought together more than 50 experts from diverse backgrounds to generate innovative ideas and strategies that can tackle this predicament.

The report synthesizes our collective ideas and proposed solutions, which include developing collaborative research approaches and partnership models to expedite polymer discovery through the integration of theory, computation, experimentation, and data analytics. It also addresses the importance of data sharing mechanisms and best practices, identifies challenges faced by different stakeholders, highlights priorities for supporting programs, tools, and services, and establishes frameworks for data sharing and access to physical infrastructure and technical resources.

Plastics are pervasive, and finding solutions at the intersection of plastics, sustainability, and environmental impact necessitates the collective efforts of all stakeholders. Users, producers, environmental experts, government agencies, academia, economists, and policy experts must collaborate to define requirements, develop sustainable materials and systems, establish acceptable standards, and ensure widespread adoption. To foster collaboration, a comprehensive roadmap with clear goals and timelines is crucial, employing a systems-level approach that balances needs, benefits, and impact to achieve a net positive effect on the planet.

The Square Table report aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current landscape of sustainable polymers, highlight key areas of interest, and explore opportunities for translating vision into innovation and partnership. We hope that this report serves as a valuable resource to guide future endeavors in sustainable polymers.
